Untitled 1.text: It is better to approach Spencer's epics from a poetic phenomenological lens than the lens of humanism which has been traditionally used to understand his texts.

Untitled 2.text: Poetic phenomenology situates the reader more acutely to the importance of context and interpersonal relations in Spencer's work.

Untitled 3.text: This focuses the reader's imagination in the singular reality and social context of Spencer's fictions.

Untitled 4.text: Poetic phenomenology thus gives us more textual access to Spencer's imagination than traditional humanism which is founded on Plato's idea of universal forms.

Untitled 5.text: Platonic transcendentalism is not the only way to access spiritual themes and symbols in Spencer's work.

Untitled 6.text: A phenomenological approach gives us greater access to the social dynamics enunciated by Spencer's use of spiritual themes.
